notes.text: In the print version of this puzzle, the columns consisting of 14-/42-Down, 16-/49-Down and 22-Down are not as wide as all the other columns. To solve an interactive digital version, go to nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2017/03/23

CELEBRITY CROSSWORD

To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted on Feb. 15, 1942, we are beginning today a series of puzzles co-constructed by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors.

The first such collaboration, below, is by the actor Jesse Eisenberg ("The Social Network," "Rio," "Now You See Me," "Batman vs. Superman: Dawn of Justice") and Patrick Blindauer (with his 55th Times contribution).

The celebrity collaborations will continue throughout the year -- at least one a month, and sometimes more often.

More information about the making of today's puzzle, along with news on future puzzles in the series, appears on the Times's crossword blog (https://www.nytimes.com/column/wordplay).

CELEBRITY CROSSWORD To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted on Feb. 15, 1942, we are beginning today a series of puzzles co-constructed by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors. The first such collaboration, below, is by the actor Jesse Eisenberg ("The Social Network," "Rio," "Now You See Me," "Batman vs. Superman: Dawn of Justice") and Patrick Blindauer (with his 55th Times contribution). The celebrity collaborations will continue throughout the year — at least one a month, and sometimes more often. More information about the making of today's puzzle, along with news on future puzzles in the series, appears on the Times's crossword blog.
The five rows of circled squares reveal an unusual feature of this puzzle.

CELEBRITY PUZZLE
To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors.
This collaboration is by the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson and his Harvard classmate Andrea Carla Michaels (with her 56th puzzle for The Times).
The celebrity collaborations will continue periodically through the year.
More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column (nytimes.com/column/wordplay).

CELEBRITY PUZZLE To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors. This collaboration is by the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson and his Harvard classmate Andrea Carla Michaels (with her 56th puzzle for The Times). The celebrity collaborations will continue periodically through the year. More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column.
In the print version of this puzzle, the clue number 7 in both the grid and clues reads "007" instead. This does not affect solving.
More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column (nytimes.com/column/wordplay).
In the print version of this puzzle, the circled part is divided by thick lines into four smaller, equal parts.

CELEBRITY CROSSWORD
    To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors.
    This collaboration is by former president Bill Clinton, an avid crossword doer, who sometimes works two or three puzzles in a day - in times that would be respectable at a crossword tournament - together with a longtime friend, a judge in Little Rock, Ark., Victor Fleming. This is Victor's 46th puzzle for The Times.
    The celebrity collaborations will continue periodically through the year.
    More information about the making of today's puzzle appears at https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/11/insider/bill-clinton-new-york-times-crossword.html
In the print version of this puzzle, the circled squares are instead shaded.
More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column (nytimes.com/column/wordplay).
More information about the making of today's puzzle appears on the Times's crossword blog.
When this puzzle is done, draw a line connecting the 11 circled letters, starting and ending in square #28, so as to spell a phrase related to the puzzle's theme.

In the newspaper and web versions of this puzzle, the black squares forming a path across the grid are instead shaded gray. After solving, read the letters along this path to get another example of the theme.
When this puzzle is done, read the letters along the shaded path to get another example of the theme.

CELEBRITY CROSSWORD
   To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors.
  This collaboration is by the comedian Elayne Boosler, who was recently named by Rolling Stone magazine as one of the "50 Best Stand-Up Comics of All Time," working together with Patrick Merrell, a writer/illustrator in Vero Beach, Fla. This is Patrick's 86th puzzle for The Times.
  The celebrity collaborations will continue periodically through the year.More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column (nytimes.com/column/wordplay).

CELEBRITY CROSSWORD To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors. This collaboration is by the comedian Elayne Boosler, who was recently named by Rolling Stone magazine as one of the "50 Best Stand-Up Comics of All Time," working together with Patrick Merrell, a writer/illustrator in Vero Beach, Fla. This is Patrick's 86th puzzle for The Times. The celebrity collaborations will continue periodically through the year. More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column.
When this puzzle is finished, read the circled letters roughly clockwise, starting with the first letter of 68-Across, to spell the name of an appropriate landmark.

To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors. This collaboration is by the designer and TV host Isaac Mizrahi, together with David J. Kahn, a retired consulting actuary in New York City. This is David's 172nd crossword for The Times. More information about the making of today's puzzle appears in the Times's daily crossword column (nytimes.com/column/wordplay).

To mark the 75th anniversary of the New York Times crossword, which debuted in 1942, we are publishing a series of puzzles co-created by famous people who solve the Times crossword, working together with regular Times puzzle contributors. This collaboration is by the designer and TV host Isaac Mizrahi, together with David J. Kahn, a retired consulting actuary in New York City. This is David's 172nd crossword for The Times. More information about the making of today's puzzle appears on the Times's crossword blog.

Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite or the mobile app, the print version contains elements that the software cannot reproduce. We recommend playing the web game to solve electronically, or using the PDF.
The 10 unclued answers in this puzzle (from 20-Across to 57-Across) comprise a word ladder, in which one letter is changed between each consecutive step.
This puzzle's clever theme is signaled by the circled letters in the middle of the grid. - Will Shortz
See 3/30 puzzle Notepad for explanation of the theme answers to this puzzle.
In 3/29 puzzle, the answer to 39-Across, when translated by the cipher key at 20- and 55-Across (A = Z, B = Y, C = X, etc.), spells OUR COVER IS BLOWN.
HEART (Clockwise): 1955 Four Aces hit (and theme of this puzzle)

In the print version, the squares at 5, 10, 45, 60, 90, 108, 139 and 140 were not numbered.  There were no clues at 5-Down, 10-Down, 45-Across, 60-Down, 90-Across, 108-Down, 139-Across or 140-Across.  Adjustments to accommodate Across Lite have resulted in the online puzzle having different clue numbers than the print version.

Each answer at 26-, 39-, 63-, 84- and 101-Across is a quiz question for which there is one correct response among the four choices in the clue. The circled letter in the answer is the correct response.

2000-09-03.title: Who Wants To Be A Quiz Show Contestant?

notes.text:
TREE
Counterclockwise
 Holiday tune
Despite appearances, every square in this themed puzzle appears in two answers, across and down.
NOTE ON 10/27 PUZZLE:  The letters in the fifth, eighth and eleventh rows, reading left to right, spell the theme entries.
This crossword contains eight interlocking theme answers -- with a wordplay twist. - Will Shortz
Note:  Across Lite will consider a correct solution to 36-Across to be XXX.
Note: In a letter bank, the letters of one word are used (and repeated as necessary) to spell a longer word or phrase. For example, IMPS is a letter bank of MISSISSIPPI.
Visual hints to the answers to the asterisked clues (*) can be found in the grid.

Every great themed crossword is based on an original idea. The theme of this one (as shown in 20-, 26-, 43- and 51-Across) is simple. But notice how the idea is carried through in the black squares and the starts of the clues. -- Will Shortz
The print version of this puzzle has white spaces following 23-Across, between 37- and 39-Across, and preceding 49-Across.
The seven circled letters, reading in order from top to bottom, will spell the title of this puzzle.
5/8/03 "Catty-corner" answers: STRAY CAT, SIAMESE CAT, FAT CAT, TOM CAT, HEP CAT, etc.
Note on 5/22 puzzle: MAN + MAN = MEN
Sixteen answers in this puzzle have something unusual in common. What is it?
They rhyme: GOOEY, PTUI, DEWEY, CHEWY, LOUIS, SUEY, BUOY, etc.
Twelve answers in this puzzle are to be entered in an unusual way, for you to discover.
The eight circled letters can be rearranged to spell an appropriate bonus word.
The circled diagonal letters will spell a hint to eight other answers in the grid.
This puzzle contains features not currently replicable digitally. Please solve using the newspaper PDF in the Print options.
Note: A certain letter of the alphabet appears in this puzzle exactly 21 times. When you have finished solving, find and connect these letters to get an appropriate design.

In Thursday's puzzle, the black square immediately preceding or following 24A, 25A, 48A, 50A, 4D, 28D, 29D and 57D should be interpreted as a "block" and considered part of the adjoining answer. For example, 24A = SUNBLOCK, 25A = BLOCK PARTY, etc.

Note on 7/9 puzzle: Lance Armstrong is a "four-time champ" of the Tour de France, going into the 2003 race, which started last weekend. If he wins again this year, he will be a "five-time champ." Either answer fits at 35-Across.
The unkeyed square to the right of #36 has this Down clue: John Philip Sousa offering. And the unkeyed square numbered 42 has this Down clue: "Little Women" family name.
18- & 22-Across and 53- & 57-Across have a hidden connection to 36-Across.
Note: The circled letters will show a "change in the weather."
Each of the three theme answers below (20-, 36- and 54-Across) can be clued with the same three letters.
The circled square has two answers.
Arrange the four circled letters in the grid to get a word that defines the four unclued answers.
The clue for the three theme answers in the 8/25 puzzle was WED.

As the central Across answer MAN IN OUTER SPACE suggests, the six words at  1-, 18-, 27-, 47-, 62- and 68-Across (CHESTER, MILITIA, HANDLE, DRAFTS, SERVANT and TRIGGER) need to be preceded or followed by MAN (MANCHESTER, MILITIAMAN, MANHANDLE, DRAFTSMAN, MANSERVANT and TRIGGERMAN) to answer their clues.
The three circled letters will spell a word that is missing from 14 answers in this puzzle.

As a demonstration of speed puzzle construction at the 28th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, on March 11 in Stamford, Conn., Mike Shenk took a theme proposed by the audience and created this puzzle, start to finish, without computer-assisted fill, in 60 minutes. Later, in a race to solve it, Trip Payne, of Boca Raton, Fla., finished first, in 3 minutes. About two-thirds of the audience completed the puzzle correctly within the 15-minute time limit.
The answers at 17- and 51-Across and 11- and 24-Down can all be defined by the same missing three-letter word. What is it?
In the 6/7 puzzle, the 10 hidden body parts are ARM, EAR, EYE, GUM, HIP, JAW, LEG, LIP, RIB and TOE.
17- and 64-Across and 11- and 34-Down each conceals an article of clothing.
Here's a fun subject for a puzzle, and there is a little surprise at 41-Across. - Will Shortz
The circled letters, starting in square #27 and reading clockwise, will spell a familiar phrase suggested by 20-, 35- and 52-Across.
Clues in 6/19 puzzle with errors: 1-, 14-, 19- and 24-Across; and 8-, 9-, 28-, 47-, 49- and 50-Down
Note on 12/30 puzzle: The word RED was needed to complete LETTER DAYS, LOBSTER, SKELTON, HOT CHILI PEPPERS, HERRING, BLOODED, EYE SPECIAL, ANT, HEAD, ALERTS, SHIRT, BREAST, CENT and INK.

Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite or the mobile app, the print version contains elements that the software cannot reproduce. We recommend playing the web game to solve electronically, or using the PDF.
In the 1/2/08 puzzle, the four lines form an O-BOW ("oboe").

Lynn Lempel is known affectionately as the Queen of Mondays. She makes puzzles with simple, elegant themes and all familiar vocabulary. The six longest Across entries in this puzzle feature a familiar progression at their ends. -- Will Shortz

TEEN PUZZLEMAKER WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, have been contributed by puzzlemakers under the age of 20. Today's crossword is by Will Nediger, 18, of London, Ontario. He is a second-year student at the University of Western Ontario. This is his sixth puzzle for The Times.
When this puzzle is finished, the 11 circled letters in reading order will spell the subject of the quote starting at 20-Across.

TEEN PUZZLEMAKER WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, have been contributed by puzzlemakers under the age of 20. Today's crossword is by Natan Last, 17, of Brooklyn. He is a first-year student at Brown University. This is his sixth puzzle for The Times.
Note on July 21 puzzle: Shifting each letter in 38-Across one letter earlier in the alphabet produces the message YOU BROKE THE CODE.
When this puzzle is done, unscramble the five circled letters to find out how the circles could have been left with the puzzle's solution still being correct
The missing clue in the 12/4 puzzle: Bud

TEEN PUZZLEMAKER WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, have been contributed by puzzlemakers under the age of 20. Today's crossword is by Caleb Madison, 15, of New York City. He is a sophomore at Bard High School in Manhattan. This is his fourth puzzle for The Times.
When this puzzle is done, connect the circled letters in alphabetical order, and then back to the start, to reveal something seen on the 32-Down 4-Down.
While most crossword grids are square, this one has an ingenious reason for being elongated. This may be my favorite Monday puzzle of all time, proving that easy can also be a wow. - Will Shortz

Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite or the mobile app, the print version contains elements that the software cannot reproduce. We recommend playing the web game to solve electronically, or using the PDF.

2008-04-02.title: Turn the completed grid into a greeting card!

notes.text: The eight two-letter answers in this puzzle are all state postal abbreviations, representing (in some order) the Beaver State, Beehive State, Big Sky Country, Heart of Dixie, Pine Tree State, Show Me State, Sunflower State and Volunteer State.

This crossword was the playoff puzzle at Lollapuzzoola, a crossword tournament directed by Brian Cimmet and Ryan Hecht, held in Jackson Heights, Queens, on August 22. The winner, Dan Feyer, of New York City, finished it perfectly in 7 minutes 10 seconds.

HALF-CENTURY PUZZLEMAKERS' WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, are by puzzlemakers who have been contributing to The Times for more than 50 years. Arthur Schulman, a retired psychology professor at the University of Virginia, had his Sunday Times debut on September 14, 1954. The puzzle below should be easy for solvers who remember their old-fashioned crossword vocabulary.
When this puzzle is completed, one letter of the alphabet will appear 22 times. Shade in its square everywhere it appears. The result will be an image suggested by 36-Across.
The four unclued answers are synonymous.
When this puzzle is done, the nine circles will contain the letters A through I. Connect them with a line, in alphabetical order, and you will form an illustration of the puzzle's theme.
The answers to the combined Across clues are anagrams of each other. The order in which the answers in each pair are to be entered in the grid is for you to discover.
The answers to the 13 starred clues have something in common.

DIAGONAL
What you might do eventually to make up for lost time
While some Across clues in this puzzle are blank, every answer is in fact clued.
When this puzzle has been completed, shade in the letters of 35-Across everywhere they appear in the grid, revealing three letters and three lines.
After finishing this puzzle, color the circled squares blue, and color all the Across answers containing an "R" red, to reveal an image related to the puzzle's theme.
The answers to the eight starred clues all have something in common, each in a different way.
When completed, this puzzle grid will contain an unusual feature that appears nine times. Can you find it?

DIAGONAL
1 Face imaginary enemies
7 1972 Bill Withers #1 hit
37 Bettor's buy
The answer at 68-Across explains this puzzle's shaded squares. This was Joanne's first-ever crossword -- quite a debut! - Will Shortz

2005-01-02.title: What People Might Say Before Doing This Puzzle

notes.text: Former President Bill Clinton, whose presidential library opened in Little Rock on Nov. 18, is a regular crossword solver. He pretested this puzzle for us, finishing it in &quot;less than an hour.&quot; (How does your time compare?) His completed solution grid will be shown next week

When this puzzle is completed, solve the maze in the grid, traveling through the openings in the squares, beginning at 69-Across, ending at 103-Down...and passing over the word spelled at 71-Across 18 times. As you proceed, the consecutive letters of 71-Across will always be in their correct order, in straight lines reading forward, backward, up or down.

HALF-CENTURY PUZZLEMAKERS' WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, are by puzzlemakers who have been contributing to The Times for more than 50 years. Lou Sabin, of Milltown, N.J., sold his first puzzle to The Times in 1950. He now constructs crosswords with his wife, Fran. Altogether Lou has had more than 150 puzzles in the paper.

HALF-CENTURY PUZZLEMAKERS' WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, are by puzzlemakers who have been contributing to The Times for more than 50 years. Charles Gersch, of New York City, had his first crossword published on February 21, 1944, when he was 13, in the New York Herald Tribune. He made his Times debut in 1951.
When this puzzle is completed, the circled letters, read in order from left to right (column by column), will reveal the name of a Mystery Person.

2004-03-21.title: Movie Sequels That Were Never Made

notes.text: When this puzzle is done, the seven circles will contain the letters from A to G. Starting with A, connect them alphabetically with one continuous line, and you'll get an image of a 39-Across.

At 14 years 2 months, Ben Pall is so far the youngest constructor I have published in The Times. The puzzle pays tribute to some pop culture icons from far before his time. - Will Shortz, January, 2017

2005-12-18.title: What The Professor Meant To Say

notes.text: For the answer to each starred clue, including the first letter is good; dropping it is bad.)
Bonus puzzle: When this crossword has been completed, try to find the word ELF hidden in the grid 20 times, word search-style -- horizontally, vertically and diagonally in any direction.

When this puzzle is done, start at the end of 57-Across; then, beginning counterclockwise, connect the circles in one continuous line to identify a figure invented by 29-Down. The answers to the five asterisked clues will provide a hint to the figure.
When this puzzle is done, interpret the answers to the seven starred clues literally, in order from top to bottom.

When the puzzle is done, the letters in the following squares spell a bonus phrase: 7A - 3rd letter, 31A - 5th, 65A - 4th, 104A - 6th, 136A - 3rd, 151A - 1st, 149A - 4th, 133A - 4th, 100A - 1st, 62A - 1st, 29A - 6th
The answers to the 9 starred clues all contain 5 letters in common, reading left to right, not necessarily consecutively.

2007-05-20.title: More Headlines That Make You Go "Huh?"

notes.text: Every letter in the answer to each asterisked clue appears an even number of times in that answer ... except one. Altogether, these eight unpaired letters can be arranged to spell the answer to 68- and 70-Across.
The 16 circled letters, starting in square #34 and proceeding roughly counterclockwise, ending at #38, will spell the opening lyric of a popular song.

Correction: March 17, 2016 
The clue for 1-Across originally read, “Upstate New York city where Mark Twain was born.”
Note: When this puzzle has been completed, the following answers will form a progression: 76A, 10D, 112A, 22A, 51A, 15D, 37A, 86D, 97A, 62D and 131A.

In the print version of this puzzle, there is a special additional clue (under the heading "AROUND") whose answer begins in the circled square. The clue is "Self-descriptive statement about a 16-Across." For the interactive experience, try solving our web game at http://nyti.ms/solveMar24.

In the print version of this puzzle, there is a special additional clue (under the heading "AROUND") whose answer begins in the shaded square. The clue is "Self-descriptive statement about a 16-Across." For the interactive experience, try solving our web game at http://nyti.ms/solveMar24.

In the newspaper version of this puzzle, there is a special additional clue (under the heading "AROUND") whose answer begins in the shaded square. The clue is "Self-descriptive statement about a 16-Across."
In the print version of this puzzle, five clues have a solid black bar in them. Here, these are represented by a string of number signs (####).

The ninth annual Lollapuzzoola crossword tournament, directed by Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer, will take place Saturday, Aug. 13, at All Souls Church in Manhattan. Information appears at bemoresmarter.com. This puzzle appeared in a prior tournament and had a 15-minute time limit.
A list of the anagrams in yesterday's clues can be found at www.nytimes.com/anagrams.

This puzzle contains an element that cannot be reproduced digitally. However, the puzzle can be solved and understood in digital format. For a full explanation of the theme, check today's column on Wordplay: www.nytimes.com/wordplay
All the clues in this crossword appear in a single list, combining Across and Down. When two answers share a number, they also share a clue.
In the print version of this puzzle, the five squares in 50-Across each have a small number in them, as follows: 5 | 29 | 47 | 34 | 43
In the print version of this puzzle, the circled squares are instead outlined in heavy black bars to form a spiral shape.
Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite, the print version contains elements that the software cannot reproduce.

When this puzzle has been completed, connect the circled letters in order from A to N to get an appropriate image.)

Diamond (starting at third square of 109-Across)

We recommend using the PDF or Web game version for solving this puzzle, as it contains elements that the software cannot reproduce. Specifically, six squares which would normally be black instead each have their four edges colored, alternating between green and red. These colored squares occur at the intersections of 31A/11D, 34A/5D, 46A/26D, 62A/45D, 92A/67D and 98A/75D.
When this puzzle is completed, take the answer to each starred clue and cross out all the letters used twice. The leftover letters will spell an appropriate word, reading top to bottom.
In the print and Web versions of this puzzle, the black square in the center of the puzzle contains an image of a compass rose.

HALF-CENTURY PUZZLEMAKERS' WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, are by puzzlemakers who have been contributing to The Times for more than 50 years. Mel Taub had his first Times crossword published on October 24, 1954. His Puns and Anagrams puzzles (of which this is an example) have appeared in the Sunday Magazine since 1955.

HALF-CENTURY PUZZLEMAKERS' WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, are by puzzlemakers who have been contributing to The Times for more than 50 years. Maura Jacobson, of Hartsdale, N.Y., published her first crossword in the Sunday Times on March 6, 1955. Her popular weekly series of puzzles for New York magazine began in 1978.

HALF-CENTURY PUZZLEMAKERS' WEEK
All the daily crosswords this week, Monday through Saturday, are by puzzlemakers who have been contributing to The Times for more than 50 years. Bernice Gordon, 95, of Philadelphia, had her first Sunday crossword published on January 23, 1955. Her first weekday puzzle appeared three years earlier. She is the oldest known puzzlemaker in the newspaper's history.
When the puzzle is done, the circled letters will spell, from top to bottom, the name of the town where all the people in this puzzle's theme once lived.)

When this puzzle is done, the answers will include a familiar series of 38-Across (minus the middle square). Connect the squares of this series in order with a line, starting with the circled square. The resulting image will be a pair of 38-Across (WITH the middle square). In addition, the clues all share a feature that provides an additional hint to the puzzle's theme.
This is the Cryptic Crossword. To access the regular crossword, please download the PDF. The regular crossword is not available in Across Lite format.
The print version of this puzzle's grid has two arrows: one pointing from 15A to 17A, and one pointing from 69A to 70A.
When this puzzle is finished, the six circled letters can be arranged to spell an answer to the catchphrase reading diagonally from upper left to lower right.

These two clues are for the center square:

Across: Shortest title of any #1 hit on the Billboard Hot 100 [Britney Spears, 2009]

Down: Length of the eight runners-up to the Across answer, all of which are answers to starred clues in this puzzle

In the print version of today's puzzle, some of the horizontal rules of the grid are not solid all the way across. They appear broken, for reasons relating to the puzzle's theme. Specifically, the horizontal rules under the following squares are not solid:
Row #3 -- under squares 5-7
Row #5 -- under squares 9-13
Row #8 -- under squares 6-10
In this crossword, every answer and every clue contains at least one letter B.
This crossword is unusual in a certain way. Can you identify how? (answer in Notepad)
When this puzzle is completed, the circled letters, starting at 21-Across and reading clockwise, will reveal the first part of 17-Across.
The answers to the 12 starred clues start with abbreviations for the months of the year, in order.
The answers to the 12 starred clues have something in common. What is it? (Answer in Notepad)
When this puzzle is done, read the eight circled letters clockwise, starting with square #24, to identify this puzzle's theme.

SECRET PHRASE CONTEST
When this puzzle has been completed, put nine holes over the grid and arrange the letters shown to form an appropriate two-word phrase (4,5). Where these holes are is for you to discover. When you have the answer, send it by e-mail to crossword@nytimes.com. Twenty-five correct solvers chosen at random, whose entries are received by midnight E.S.T. Sunday, Nov. 7, will receive copies of "The New York Times Little Black and White Book of Holiday Crosswords." Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners' names will appear on Friday, Nov. 12, at www.nytimes.com/wordplay.
This puzzle by Liz Gorski is remarkable for its stunning grid art, which suggests the puzzle's theme beautifully. -- Will Shortz
Bonus question: What word can follow each half of the answer to each starred clue?
BOARD
The words in the circled spaces will spell a quotation from Linus Pauling)
When this puzzle is done, a bonus message will appear in the circled boxes reading from top to bottom.)

When this puzzle is done, the seven circled letters can be arranged to spell a common word, which is missing from seven of the clues, as indicated by [ ]. Connect the seven letters in order with a line and you will get an outline of the object that the word names.

notes.text: When this puzzle is completed, connect the circled letters in alphabetical order from A to R to show the outline of an 84-Across.

2010-08-15.title: Is There An Echo In Here?

notes.text: This puzzle may be solved in Across Lite or the Java applet as a normal crossword. However, since it contains bonus elements that cannot be rendered electronically, we encourage solvers to print out the PDF that is also being offered.
Each set of circled letters is described by an answer elsewhere in the grid.

In the regular print version of this puzzle, the clues for 27-, 38- and 47-Across include words in foreign alphabets which cannot be displayed in Across Lite. In these cases, English-letter transliterations have been substituted.

2011-01-09.title: The Long And Short Of It

notes.text: Every length of answer from 3 to 15 letters - except one - appears in this puzzle. Some people might have a 1-Across about that.
Some of the black squares in this puzzle's grid provide a hint to the four longest Down answers.
When this puzzle is done, connect the four V's with a square, the three K's with an upside-down L, and each K diagonally to the nearest V. Then draw a circle around the only X.
When this puzzle is done, the 11 circled letters can be connected by a curved line to spell a two-word phrase appropriate to this puzzle's theme.
When this puzzle is done, you will find that the ends of the answers to the five starred clues, when in the 15-/67-Across, comprise a 1-/71-Across.

Four answers in this puzzle are missing the same eight-letter clue - a single word that can be spelled from the eight circled letters. When the puzzle is done, connect the circled letters in order with a line, and you will get an outline of the object the word names.

This crossword was the playoff puzzle at Lollapuzzoola 4, a tournament held in New York City on Aug. 6, conducted by Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer. The champion, Jeffrey Harris, completed it in less than 9 minutes.
Two hints for 17- and 57-Across and 11- and 26-Down appear somewhere in this puzzle.

"CROSS" WORDS CONTEST
All the puzzles this week, from Monday to Saturday, have been created by one person, Patrick Berry. Have your solutions handy, because the Saturday puzzle conceals a meta-challenge involving the solution grids of all six. When you have the answer to the meta-challenge, mail it to: crossword@nytimes.com. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6:00 p.m. E.T. Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of "Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times." Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners' names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at http://www.nytimes.com/wordplay.

Note: This substitute puzzle was provided for digital solvers due to technical constraints. The puzzle that ran in the paper can be found at nytimes.com/svc/crosswords/v2/puzzle/print/Oct2111.pdf
Parts of 15 answers in this puzzle are missing, in a manner for you to discover.
This puzzle has two bonus answers in appropriate places. Can you find them?
A breezy, handsomely constructed puzzle whose theme is revealed at 52-Across. - Will Shortz
When this puzzle is completed, the 10 circled letters, read from top to bottom, will spell a name associated with 39-Across.

Due to the unusual structure of this grid, please note the following for solving in Across Lite

Across Lite for Mac and Windows:
Use arrow keys or mouse to select the interior squares to enter letters. Tab keys will not select them. There is no clue associated with these interior squares.

Across Lite for iPad:
The interior letters CANNOT be entered in v3.0 of the app.
When this crossword is done, the puzzle's theme will help you fill the interior squares.
The circled letters in this puzzle, when read in the correct order, spell the name of a shape. The four unclued answers are common three-word phrases usually accompanied by this shape.
Parts of six answers have been entered in the grid for you.
The circles in this puzzle are contained in words that form a sequence. Connect these circles, in the order of the sequence, to form an appropriate image.
When this puzzle is done, the answers to the six starred clues will form a word ladder, starting with 4-Across, whose record of 33-/42-Across was broken by 68-Across.
The seven circled letters reading from top to bottom describe an event occurring at four locations in this puzzle.
Four answers in this puzzle are incomplete. The missing part can be found in four other places in the grid.
This puzzle features elements that cannot be duplicated in electronic formats. We strongly suggest using the PDF file instead.
This puzzle has the record for fewest words, at 50. That's twenty fewer than the average themeless crossword, making it a real achievement of crossword construction.

The answer to each starred clue is a compound word or a familiar two-word phrase. A certain four-letter word (spelled out clockwise by the circled squares) can follow the first half and precede the second half of each of these answers, in each case to complete another compound word or familiar two-word phrase.
This clever puzzle is a collaboration that was done entirely by email. At the time it was made, the two constructors had never met face to face! - Will Shortz
This puzzle contains the following additional clue after the Across and Down clues: DIAGONAL 1. Annual message
What Generation Gap? The only collab I know of between a Young constructor (David Steinberg) and our Oldest (Bernice Gordon). -- Will Shortz

From Will Shortz: Crosswords Contest
The crossword for Sunday, Sept. 22, will be a special contest puzzle. The crossword itself can be solved in all the usual online formats. However, to solve the bonus contest element, you will need to see some heavy outlines in the grid, which cannot be reproduced electronically. Thus, if you plan to enter the contest, please print out the PDF version of the puzzle, which will be made available at the same time as the electronic version.
Good luck!
A certain three-letter word, appropriate to this puzzle's theme, goes in the unnumbered center square.

Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite, the print version includes elements that cannot be duplicated in the software. We recommend downloading and printing out the PDF version.

When this puzzle is done, the circled letters, reading from left to right and top to bottom, will reveal who wrote the seven songs in the theme.
This puzzle has features not possible to duplicate in Across Lite. We highly recommend solving the PDF version.
Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite, there are elements in the print version that cannot be duplicated electronically. We recommend using the PDF for the best solving experience.
After this puzzle was created, the constructor did something to 11 squares - as suggested by a two-word reading of 63-Across before alteration.

Although this puzzle can be solved in this format, there are elements in the print version that cannot be duplicated electronically. We recommend using the newspaper PDF for the best solving experience.
The newspaper version of this puzzle has one oversize square for each block of 4 circles. We recommend that you solve the PDF version ... but this electronic version is provided as well.
The answers to the 13 starred clues follow an unusual two-way progression from 1- to 73-Across. Can you figure out what it is?
The first letters of the answers proceed from A to M; the last letters proceed backward from Z to N.
In the digital version of this puzzle, the theme answer begins in the second square of 23-Across.
When this puzzle is done, the seven circled letters, reading clockwise, will spell a phrase relating to the puzzle's theme.

In the solution to the 7/10/14 puzzle, the answers to 5-, 54- and 63-Across, and 4-, 12- and 50-Down, are preceded by the invisible word SILENT. Additionally, each answer word crossing these contains a silent letter at the crossing point.

This crossword was the most-discussed puzzle at Lollapuzzoola 7, a tournament held on August 9 in New York City. The event was directed by Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer. Hint: The title is key to solving the puzzle. Time limit: 45 minutes.
The human body is said to have 10 three-letter body parts. All 10 of these are hidden inside Across answers in this puzzle. Can you find them all?

All the puzzles this week, from Monday to Saturday, have been created by one person, Patrick Blindauer. Keep your solutions handy, because the Saturday puzzle conceals a meta-challenge involving the solution grids of all six. When you have the answer to the meta-challenge, send it to crossword@nytimes.com. Twenty correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6:00 p.m. E.T. Sunday, Oct. 26, 2014, will win one-year online subscriptions to the New York Times crossword. Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners' names will appear on Friday, Oct. 31, at www.nytimes.com/wordplay.

Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite or the mobile app, the print version contains elements that the software cannot reproduce. We recommend playing the web game to solve electronically, or using the PDF.

After completing this puzzle, connect nine appropriate letters in order to discover an image associated with 44-Down.

The last names of eight U.S. presidents are hidden in this puzzle's completed grid, reading across, back, up, down and diagonally, word-search style. Can you find them all?
When this puzzle is done, the circled letters, reading from top to bottom, will spell something that belongs in the center square.
When completed, the outer squares in this puzzle will contain each of the 26 letters of the alphabet exactly once.
This puzzle seemingly has more than one solution ... but only one is "correct."

From just their clues, STALACTITE and STALAGMITE can be entered in either order. However, since stalactites project from the ceiling and stalagmites from the ground, there is only one "correct" solution (the one accepted as correct by the software).
The five Across answers with only years for clues are the five most recent members of a particular category.

In yesterday's (6/4/15) puzzle, from just their clues, STALACTITE and STALAGMITE could be entered in either order. However, since stalactites project from the ceiling and stalagmites from the ground, there was only one "correct" solution.

Although this puzzle can be solved electronically, there are elements in the print version that could not be duplicated in Across Lite. For the full solving experience, please use the print or web version.
When this puzzle is done, four squares will remain empty. Which ones and why are for you to determine.
When this puzzle is done, four squares will remain empty. Which ones and why are for you to determine. (Across Lite solvers should put the letter B in these blank squares.)
Answer to 8/27: CB RADIO, HG WELLS, DC UNITED, BA BARACUS, UT DALLAS, PO BOXES and TS ELIOT each started with two consecutive letters in reverse alphabetical order.
Seven Across answers in this puzzle have a highly unusual property for which we can't think of a single other common example. What is the property?
CB RADIO, HG WELLS, DC UNITED, BA BARACUS, UT DALLAS, PO BOXES and TS ELIOT each start with two consecutive letters in reverse alphabetical order
We asked some favorite Times crossword contributors, "What would you like to do in a daily Times crossword that has never been done before?" This week's puzzles, Monday to Saturday, are the result.
We asked some favorite Times crossword contributors, "What would you like to do in a daily Times crossword that has never been done before?" This week's puzzles, Monday to Saturday, are the result.
The first 3 letters of 61-Across are shaded in the print edition.

The Across Lite, iOS and Windows app versions of this puzzle were not able to publish four math symbols that should appear in certain squares, as follows: Square 2: /, square 5: -, square 11: + and square 42: x.
The answers to this puzzle's four starred clues can each precede a hidden word in 16-, 27-, 43- and 59-Across.
We asked some favorite Times crossword contributors, "What would you like to do in a daily Times crossword that has never been done before?" This week's puzzles, Monday to Saturday, are the result.
We asked some favorite Times crossword contributors, "What would you like to do in a daily Times crossword that has never been done before?" This week's puzzles, Monday to Saturday, are the result.
The four long Across answers are affected by a literal interpretation of the shaded boxes.
The four long Across answers are affected by a literal interpretation of the circled boxes.
The circled letters in this puzzle provide a hint to the starts of the answers to the four starred clues.
Today's grid contains two images overlaid on the black squares, which this format does not currently support. You can find the images here: nyti.ms/clue37A.
We asked some favorite Times crossword contributors, "What would you like to do in a daily Times crossword that has never been done before?" This week's puzzles, Monday to Saturday, are the result.

Today's grid contains two images overlaid on the black squares, which this format does not support. To solve the crossword in digital form, visit this link: nyti.ms/oct1215web. To print the grid with images, visit this link: nyti.ms/oct1215pdf.

Today's grid contains two images overlaid on the black squares, which this format doesn't support. To solve the crossword in digital form, visit this link: nyti.ms/oct1215web. To see the grid with images, visit this link: nyti.ms/oct1215pdf.

When this puzzle is done, the circles will contain five different letters of the alphabet. Connect each set of circles containing the same letter, without crossing your line, to make a simple closed shape. The resulting five closed shapes together will form a picture of a 117-Across. The five letters can be arranged to name a good place to get a 117-Across.
The New York Public Library turns 100 on May 23.

2011-05-22.title: Happy Birthday, New York Public Library!

notes.text: Ten famous people are attending a costume party in this crossword. After the grid is filled, change the two circled letters in each theme answer to "unmask" a celebrity.

Although this Across Lite version does work, due to features that cannot be duplicated electronically, it is recommended that solvers download and print out the PDF version of this puzzle. As a second-best alternative, print out this Across Lite version and solve on paper.
In the circled squares of this crossword, the Across and Down answers do not actually cross. Write both parts in those squares. Then use the central Across answer to interpret them properly to spell an appropriate final word.
When this puzzle is done, look for a name (hinted at by 37-Down) hidden 17 times in the grid, each reading forward, backward, down, up or diagonally, word search-style.
With daylight saving time ending tonight, you have an extra hour to work on this extra-hard, oversize puzzle.
Fourteen symmetrically placed answers in this puzzle are each missing a part ... which can be found elsewhere in the grid.

2013-02-10.title: I Heard You The First Time

2013-03-24.title: You'll Know It When You See It

notes.text: In honor of the late, beloved crossword constructor Merl Reagle, today we present a classic puzzle of his from the 1999 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

When this puzzle is done, take the answers to the 10 starred clues and arrange them across and down in crossword fashion in the central 5x5 box. Due to software limitations, Across Lite and our other apps can only accept one solution, but two possibilities exist. The resulting five-letter word spelled out diagonally by the circles will answer the question asked at 23-, 34-, 91- and 107-Across.
In the print version of this puzzle, the square after 43-Across is a black circle rather than a black square.

2012-07-29.title: Debut Promos At The World's Fair

notes.text:
This puzzle's grid represents a sealed vault and its well-guarded surroundings. After completing the crossword, start in the upper-left corner and find a safe path to an important item. Then determine where to use this item to access the vault and its contents.

To enter the contest, identify the following 10 things: a) the name of the "important item," b) where to use it, c) seven hazards to avoid, and d) the contents of the vault. Each of these things is named by a single word.

When you have found the 10 words, send them in an e-mail to: crossword@nytimes.com. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern time on Tuesday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of "The New York Times Sunday Crossword Puzzles 2013 Weekly Planner Calendar" (Andrews McMeel). Only one entry per person, please. The answer grid will appear next week. The winners' names will appear in the issue of Nov. 4.
When this puzzle is done, draw a line connecting the 21 circled letters from A to U in alphabetical order. The resulting shape will provide a clue to 6-, 8-, 14-, 53- and 70-Down.
Nominees are denoted with asterisks.
When this puzzle is done, the circled letters, reading counterclockwise from the top, will spell a phrase relating to the puzzle's theme.
Complete the puzzle. Then connect the circled letters alphabetically from A to S to get an image related to the puzzle's theme.
When this puzzle is completed, the eight circled letters, starting in the upper left and proceeding roughly clockwise, will spell an appropriate word... or a different appropriate word.
The circled letters, when read clockwise, will reveal a quote from Gertrude Stein.

2014-07-13.title: We Hold These Truths To Be Self-Evident

notes.text: Crosswords Contest! In this special contest crossword, the completed grid conceals a familiar three-word phrase related to the puzzle's theme. 70-Across provides a hint as to where to find it, and you will need to print out the PDF to see some heavy lines that cannot be reproduced here (http://select.nytimes.com/premium/xword/2013/09/22/Sep2213.pdf). When you have the answer, e-mail it to crossword@nytimes.com. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern time on Tuesday, Sept. 24, will receive copies of The New York Times Sunday Crossword Puzzles 2014 Day-to-Day Calendar, courtesy of Andrews McMeel. Only one entry per person, please. The answer will appear here on Wednesday, Sept. 25. The winners' names will be announced on Friday, Sept. 27.

The grid represents a maze. Enter the room at the upper left and exit at the lower right, following a path that will become apparent as you solve the crossword. When the puzzle is done, read the circled letters in the order in which the rooms are visited to spell a quote by 153-Across.
When this puzzle is completed, an apt phrase can be found by starting at the top central letter and reading clockwise.

Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite, the print version contains elements that the software cannot reproduce. We recommend using the PDF, or alternatively one of the other available electronic versions.

2015-04-05.title: The Captain Goes Down With The Ship

notes.text: In the print and PDF versions of this puzzle, all of the circled squares are shaded light gray rather than being circled.

The answer to each starred clue must have two consecutive letters removed before it is written into the grid. These letters will move to a pair of circles elsewhere in the puzzle. (In all cases, new words will be formed.) The nine letter pairs, when properly arranged, will spell an appropriate answer at 72-Across.
When this puzzle is completed, 12 squares will be filled with a certain keyboard symbol - which will have a different signification in the Across answers than it does in the Downs.
Today's puzzle contains a feature that the app is unequipped to handle. For the best solving experience, please try the web version of today's crossword.

When this puzzle is finished, 12 special squares, along with the circled squares, will create an image of 56-Down. The 12 squares corresponding to the "reflection" of the special squares, when read clockwise from top left, will spell an alternative name for 56-Down.

When this puzzle is completed, the circled letters will form a path (starting in the first circle of 93-Across) spelling out the puzzle's theme. Each long Down answer contains a hidden city, reading in order from top to bottom, not necessarily consecutively. The location of the city, and its number of letters, are indicated.
The answers to 23-, 31-, 45-, 62-, 69-, 90-, 103- and 115-Across are themselves clues to the names spelled by their circled letters.
The print version of this puzzle contains small arrows between certain squares, which this software cannot reproduce. We recommend using the web version or the PDF.
